conclusion: The thickness of the tank wall isn't explicitly given, but we'll work with what we have.
The refractive index of the tank material is n = sqrt(3).
People inside the tank can see a maximum external angle of 120°.
Points A and B represent the inside of the tank.
Points C and D represent the exterior of the tank.
The height (or thickness) between these surfaces is 18 cm.
When light travels from one medium to another, it follows Snell's law: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2).
Light travels from air (outside) with n1 = 1 to the material with n2 = sqrt(3).
The maximum viewable angle of 120° means that the person can see 60° to the left and 60° to the right from normal.
The critical angle is the maximum angle of incidence in the denser medium (tank material) that allows light to escape into the less dense medium (air).
The critical angle theta_c is given by: sin(theta_c) = 1/sqrt(3).
Calculating: sin(theta_c) = 1/sqrt(3) = sqrt(3)/3.
theta_c = sin^(-1)(sqrt(3)/3) ≈ 30°.
If the maximum external viewing angle is 120°, this means the person inside can see up to 60° from the normal in either direction.
When rays of light reach the critical angle inside the tank material, they will refract at 90° (parallel to the tank wall) on the outside.
For a ray of light coming at the critical angle theta_c = 30°, from the inside of the tank, a ray travels at angle theta_c = 30° from the normal.
The ray then bends to 90° at the exterior boundary.
The tangent of the critical angle equals the ratio of half the viewable distance to the wall thickness: tan(30°) = (d/2)/18.
Calculating: tan(30°) = 1/sqrt(3) = (d/2)/18.
Solving for d: (d/2)/18 = 1/sqrt(3).
